docs.lead_paragraph: The trial that will decide the fate of Detroit, the largest city ever to seek bankruptcy protection, began as a lawyer for the city on Wednesday urged a judge to approve the city’s blueprint for shedding $7 billion of its debts.

headline.main: Detroit Plan for Its Debt Is Debated in Court
headline.print_headline: Detroit Plan for Its Debt Is Debated in Court

docs.abstract: Lawyers debate Detroit's bankruptcy plan on first day of trial that will decide fate of city's financial future; council for city urges judge to approve blueprint for shedding $7 billion in debt and devoting about $1.5 billion to restoring services over next decade; creditors remain split over their response to plan.
docs.snippet: The trial that will decide the fate of Detroit, the largest city ever to seek bankruptcy protection, began as a lawyer for the city on Wednesday urged a judge to approve the city’s blueprint for shedding $7 billion of its debts.

docs.lead_paragraph: After four years of very slow growth, the spending increase is linked to expanded coverage through the Affordable Care Act and to improvements in the economy.

headline.main: After Slow Growth, Experts Say, Health Spending Is Expected to Climb
headline.print_headline: After Slow Growth, Experts Say, Health Spending Is Expected to Climb

docs.abstract: Government experts predict rebound in national health care spending as expansions in coverage and improvements in the economy take hold after four years of exceptionally slow growth; link increase to expanded coverage under the Affordable Care Act, faster economic growth, and an aging population.
docs.snippet: After four years of very slow growth, the spending increase is linked to expanded coverage through the Affordable Care Act and to improvements in the economy.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: If the pattern continues, as the Congressional Budget Office forecasts, it will be a rarity in the Medicare program’s history.

headline.main: Per Capita Medicare Spending Is Actually Falling
headline.print_headline: Surprise: Per Capita Medicare Spending Is Falling

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Medicare spending is falling on a per-person basis, and if the pattern continues, as the Congressional Budget Office forecasts, it will be a rarity in the program's history; factors for pattern include the baby boom generation entering the program and Medicare patients using fewer expensive medical services.
docs.snippet: If the pattern continues, as the Congressional Budget Office forecasts, it will be a rarity in the Medicare program’s history.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. healthcare spending is expected to grow more slowly in the coming decade as a sluggish economic recovery and higher cost sharing in private insurance plans limit demand for services, a government report released on Wednesday said.

headline.main: U.S. Healthcare Spending Growth to Slow Further: Government Report
headline.print_headline: U.S. Healthcare Spending Growth to Slow Further: Government Report

docs.snippet: U.S. healthcare spending is expected to grow more slowly in the coming decade as a sluggish economic recovery and higher cost sharing in private insurance plans limit demand for services, a government report released on Wednesday said.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's respite from troublesome health care inflation is ending, the government said Wednesday in a report that renews a crucial budget challenge for lawmakers, taxpayers, businesses and patients.

headline.main: Gov't Forecasts Rising Health Care Inflation
headline.print_headline: Gov't Forecasts Rising Health Care Inflation

docs.snippet: The nation's respite from troublesome health care inflation is ending, the government said Wednesday in a report that renews a crucial budget challenge for lawmakers, taxpayers, businesses and patients.

headline.main: ZenPayroll Gives Small Business the Tech Tools of Big Business

docs.abstract: For all the crowing about small business as economic driver, big companies seem to get all the good business software. Now a group of cloud services are focusing on the little guy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Carrying identification documents and bitterness over their sudden joblessness, hundreds of ex-casino workers began filing for unemployment Wednesday morning, the first attendees at an assistance center that expects to process 5,000 newly laid-off workers over the next three days.
